blog.name: liliesflowers
blog.title: S T O N K !
blog.description:
Sometimes I draw. But mostly I cry over stories. 
--TV series, web series, books, comics, games, all kinds of storytelling will do.

tags: Then I go and bother my phd in physics brother about it
summary: First Captain Marvel, then the black hole picture (which led me to read a lot of stuff about the universe, again) and now Star...
body: First Captain Marvel, then the black hole picture (which led me to read a lot of stuff about the universe, again) and now Star Wars: it’s space-obsession month everybody!!!

blog.title: lesbian ally thor
blog.description: nathalie | formerly @ jewishjaybird | gay | stan loona and thor only | my most popular post is about megamind so if that's any indication of my page

summary: i’ve seen so much about how carol was being cocky in the endgame trailer as if every single male character in the mcu hasn’t...
body: i’ve seen so much about how carol was being cocky in the endgame trailer as if every single male character in the mcu hasn’t been cocky for 10 years. if tony stark said the same thing she said twitter would have been like “lmao mood” but since it’s her you call it cocky and annoying?? hmm. i just think it’s funny.

reblog.comment: i’ve seen so much about how carol was being cocky in the endgame trailer as if every single male character in the mcu hasn’t been cocky for 10 years. if tony stark said the same thing she said twitter would have been like “lmao mood” but since it’s her you call it cocky and annoying?? hmm. i just think it’s funny.

title: imagine this -
body:
carol danvers never takes a shortcut in her race with maria to get to base.

as a result -

carol danvers isn’t the first to doctor lawson.

carol danvers isn’t the one who volunteers to fly the plane.

carol danvers isn’t the one who shoots the energy system and absorbs its power.

carol danvers isn’t the one abducted to hala and made kree, with no memories of how she came to be there.

no.

maria rambeau is.

maria rameau ‘dies’ so honourably the air force can never mention her name again. the air force can also never let carol danvers fly again.

apparently.

she is told, in no uncertain terms, that her options are as follows

  1. accept an honourable discharge and a staggering amount of money to go away and keep her mouth shut.
  2. refuse both, go to the press and get her ass kicked into a black site until the end of time.

bullied and forced into the first option, carol finds herself with the following 

  • more money than she wants or knows what to do with 
  • a dead wife she can only ever publicly acknowledge as her best friend 
  • a child…sort of 

monica is four and a half. carol isn’t sure just how much monica understands about what’s happened and is happening. carol knows that her daughter has always been intuitive for her age, but even so, at four and a half death is a hard concept to understand - 

especially when carol finds it devastatingly hard to believe that maria is actually dead and gone. there was no body. or, there’s no body that the air force intends on releasing. hell there wasn’t even a military funeral. 

just a funeral. 

after which the rambeau’s took monica to their home for a few days. and carol proceeded to get drunk. 

six weeks later she is still drunk. drunk in a booth, on her own, trying desperately to black out because at least when she’s unconscious she’s not thinking about maria. thinking about maria is painful, terribly so and to the point that carol would rather not think about her at all. except that’s not possible. 

she can’t stop thinking about maria. 

thinking about the first time they held hands. 

the first time they kissed. 

the first time they shared a bed. 

there are a litany of moments that chase carol through her waking hours. so much so it takes her several seconds to realise that someone is sitting across from her in the booth 

what happens next goes as follows 

“fuck off.” carol slurs, her fist curling around the beer in front of her. 

it may her sixth. or her tenth. or her, who the hell cares. 

“say that again to me.” the woman across from carol says, and carol is just sober enough to recognise that name, that tone, for her head to snap up. 

“mrs. rambeau,” she slurs, trying to straighten her spine, trying to appear less absolutely shit-faced “i’m-how-what are you doing here?” 

“i’m here because you’re going to drink yourself to death.” monica’s mother says, and she’s swimming in front of carol, there are two of her, then three, then one. 

“and?” carol frowns. 

“and that’s a stupid idea.” 

“i don’t think so.” carol says. 

“oh really?” mrs. rambeau counters “what about your daughter? your daughter needs you.” 

carols head snaps up. she blinks slowly, unfurling her hand from around the warm glass of her beer “i thought…” she starts, stops. 

“i know what you thought, it’s a lot of the same things my daughter thought. but she’s,” mrs. rambeau slips “she’s gone and i’ve found myself doing a lot of thinking, a lot of praying. i do not understand what you and my daughter shared. but i do understand that you love monica, and that your absence in her life is causing her more pain. pain she does not need.” 

carol doesn’t know what to say. she swallows hard, and mrs. rambeau continues “also,” she takes a shaking breath, “you loved my daughter. that much i think i’ve known for a long time and it would be a dishonour on her memory if you drowned yourself in a bottle, and if i let you do it.” 

faced with that, carol finds herself staggering into the passenger seat of a car and then, in what feels like the blink of an eye, waking up on the rambeau’s couch. 

she’s hungover. 

she’s hurting in more ways than she knows how to describe, and, 

she sees monica watching her from the doorway, asking in a small voice “can we watch cartoons? it’s saturday.” 

carol decides she can do this. 

for maria. for monica. 

later on, when monica is playing outside, carol and the rambeau’s have a conversation in the cramped kitchen. they explain to her that if she’s going to be here, play a pivotal role in monica’s life, she’s going to be sober and employed. 

they care very little for the amount of money in carol’s bank account, but they do agree that a swath of land in lousiana could serve as a fresh start. something that could do them all a great deal of good. 

so they move. 

carol thinks about how maria would have loved it here, in the quiet and the fresh air. 

carol thinks about maria every day. 

every day for six years. 

time passes, she works as a mechanic and then more or less runs her own shop. less of a shop and more of a drop in service that gives her the free time to be with monica and the rambeau’s. it’s not the life she imagined. 

but it’s something. 

it’s a life. 

it’s enough. 

then, of course, someone sidles into her workshop all 

“i’m looking for someone named carol danvers.” 

and monica is running over because this goddamn ghost of a person looks just like her mom and carol is, 

well, 

she is skeptical in the same moment that her heart is soaring. she’s grabbing a wrench and she’s saying 

monica, honey, get behind me. 

because maria was dead and gone and she can’t possibly be standing here, with some strange dude behind her. he’s a government type, that much is obvious maria though? carol can’t pin her down. she looks the same, and yet different. 

it scares her. 

she has monica behind her back with one hand, and a wrench in the other. 

she’s facing monica down and saying “what, no, honey i’m home?” 

monica blinks, no smile, no recognition, only 

“i’m not the person you think i am.” 

carol’s stomach twists. 

of course, mrs. rambeau, three years a widow, comes running out from the house. before carol can stop her, and not as if carol could stop her if she wanted to because, well 

mrs. rambeau has no question about the fact that the woman standing before her is her previously dead daughter. 

things get even less straight forward after that. 

carol finds herself sitting in the kitchen with her sort of no-longer-dead-wife, explaining that her name isn’t beau, that she’s not a kree. carol finds herself with tears in her eyes and fighting to reach across the table and take her not-so-dead-wife’s hand. 

carol also finds herself putting down the wrench because this woman, this woman is her wife. it’s her wife and her wife isn’t dead. she has these superpowers and this sadness in her eyes. but she’s alive, and that’s enough for carol. 

not long after that, carol is shamed into participating in a rescue mission of sorts by both her daughter and her mother-in-law. she finds herself a cockpit for the first time in six years. she finds herself in space, then a spaceship, and then a dogfight. 

she finds herself watching her wife, fly around, glowing like a goddamn glowstick. 

she finds herself in lousiana, having dinner with aliens and fielding a job offer from some guy named nick and, 

and preparing to say good-bye to her wife. she can tell from the look in maria’s eyes as the aliens talk that she’s going to help them 

“i’ve found my family, i have to help them find theirs.” 

and of course she is, carol expects nothing less. 

it hurts all the same though. monica standing by carols side, watching her mom prepare to leave, leather jacket around her shoulders. she swims in it. 

carol watches maria leave, unsure when she’ll be back, but holding a pager in her hand carol knows that at some point, 

maria will return.

  • a child…sort of 

monica is four and a half. carol isn’t sure just how much monica understands about what’s happened and is happening. carol knows that her daughter has always been intuitive for her age, but even so, at four and a half death is a hard concept to understand - 

especially when carol finds it devastatingly hard to believe that maria is actually dead and gone. there was no body. or, there’s no body that the air force intends on releasing. hell there wasn’t even a military funeral. 

just a funeral. 

after which the rambeau’s took monica to their home for a few days. and carol proceeded to get drunk. 

six weeks later she is still drunk. drunk in a booth, on her own, trying desperately to black out because at least when she’s unconscious she’s not thinking about maria. thinking about maria is painful, terribly so and to the point that carol would rather not think about her at all. except that’s not possible. 

she can’t stop thinking about maria. 

thinking about the first time they held hands. 

the first time they kissed. 

the first time they shared a bed. 

there are a litany of moments that chase carol through her waking hours. so much so it takes her several seconds to realise that someone is sitting across from her in the booth 

what happens next goes as follows 

“fuck off.” carol slurs, her fist curling around the beer in front of her. 

it may her sixth. or her tenth. or her, who the hell cares. 

“say that again to me.” the woman across from carol says, and carol is just sober enough to recognise that name, that tone, for her head to snap up. 

“mrs. rambeau,” she slurs, trying to straighten her spine, trying to appear less absolutely shit-faced “i’m-how-what are you doing here?” 

“i’m here because you’re going to drink yourself to death.” monica’s mother says, and she’s swimming in front of carol, there are two of her, then three, then one. 

“and?” carol frowns. 

“and that’s a stupid idea.” 

“i don’t think so.” carol says. 

“oh really?” mrs. rambeau counters “what about your daughter? your daughter needs you.” 

carols head snaps up. she blinks slowly, unfurling her hand from around the warm glass of her beer “i thought…” she starts, stops. 

“i know what you thought, it’s a lot of the same things my daughter thought. but she’s,” mrs. rambeau slips “she’s gone and i’ve found myself doing a lot of thinking, a lot of praying. i do not understand what you and my daughter shared. but i do understand that you love monica, and that your absence in her life is causing her more pain. pain she does not need.” 

carol doesn’t know what to say. she swallows hard, and mrs. rambeau continues “also,” she takes a shaking breath, “you loved my daughter. that much i think i’ve known for a long time and it would be a dishonour on her memory if you drowned yourself in a bottle, and if i let you do it.” 

faced with that, carol finds herself staggering into the passenger seat of a car and then, in what feels like the blink of an eye, waking up on the rambeau’s couch. 

she’s hungover. 

she’s hurting in more ways than she knows how to describe, and, 

she sees monica watching her from the doorway, asking in a small voice “can we watch cartoons? it’s saturday.” 

carol decides she can do this. 

for maria. for monica. 

later on, when monica is playing outside, carol and the rambeau’s have a conversation in the cramped kitchen. they explain to her that if she’s going to be here, play a pivotal role in monica’s life, she’s going to be sober and employed. 

they care very little for the amount of money in carol’s bank account, but they do agree that a swath of land in lousiana could serve as a fresh start. something that could do them all a great deal of good. 

so they move. 

carol thinks about how maria would have loved it here, in the quiet and the fresh air. 

carol thinks about maria every day. 

every day for six years. 

time passes, she works as a mechanic and then more or less runs her own shop. less of a shop and more of a drop in service that gives her the free time to be with monica and the rambeau’s. it’s not the life she imagined. 

but it’s something. 

it’s a life. 

it’s enough. 

then, of course, someone sidles into her workshop all 

“i’m looking for someone named carol danvers.” 

and monica is running over because this goddamn ghost of a person looks just like her mom and carol is, 

well, 

she is skeptical in the same moment that her heart is soaring. she’s grabbing a wrench and she’s saying 

monica, honey, get behind me. 

because maria was dead and gone and she can’t possibly be standing here, with some strange dude behind her. he’s a government type, that much is obvious maria though? carol can’t pin her down. she looks the same, and yet different. 

it scares her. 

she has monica behind her back with one hand, and a wrench in the other. 

she’s facing monica down and saying “what, no, honey i’m home?” 

monica blinks, no smile, no recognition, only 

“i’m not the person you think i am.” 

carol’s stomach twists. 

of course, mrs. rambeau, three years a widow, comes running out from the house. before carol can stop her, and not as if carol could stop her if she wanted to because, well 

mrs. rambeau has no question about the fact that the woman standing before her is her previously dead daughter. 

things get even less straight forward after that. 

carol finds herself sitting in the kitchen with her sort of no-longer-dead-wife, explaining that her name isn’t beau, that she’s not a kree. carol finds herself with tears in her eyes and fighting to reach across the table and take her not-so-dead-wife’s hand. 

carol also finds herself putting down the wrench because this woman, this woman is her wife. it’s her wife and her wife isn’t dead. she has these superpowers and this sadness in her eyes. but she’s alive, and that’s enough for carol. 

not long after that, carol is shamed into participating in a rescue mission of sorts by both her daughter and her mother-in-law. she finds herself a cockpit for the first time in six years. she finds herself in space, then a spaceship, and then a dogfight. 

she finds herself watching her wife, fly around, glowing like a goddamn glowstick. 

she finds herself in lousiana, having dinner with aliens and fielding a job offer from some guy named nick and, 

and preparing to say good-bye to her wife. she can tell from the look in maria’s eyes as the aliens talk that she’s going to help them 

“i’ve found my family, i have to help them find theirs.” 

and of course she is, carol expects nothing less. 

it hurts all the same though. monica standing by carols side, watching her mom prepare to leave, leather jacket around her shoulders. she swims in it. 

carol watches maria leave, unsure when she’ll be back, but holding a pager in her hand carol knows that at some point, 

maria will return.
trail.content_abstract:
carol danvers never takes a shortcut in her race with maria to get to base.

as a result -

carol danvers isn’t the first to doctor lawson.

carol danvers isn’t the one who volunteers to fly the plane.

carol danvers isn’t the one who shoots the energy system and absorbs its power.

carol danvers isn’t the one abducted to hala and made kree, with no memories of how she came to be there.

no.

maria rambeau is.

summary: i should be doing my assignments, but I took thirty minutes to make a rough painting of a Kree Civilian from lower Hala instead...
body:
i should be doing my assignments, but I took thirty minutes to make a rough painting of a Kree Civilian from lower Hala instead aslaksdjlakjsdka

It’s really rough because I was just trying to get an idea down. No short skirts or whatever here, since I figure Lower Hala is cooler than Upper Hala, what with them being largely shielded by Upper Hala from the sun and (presumably) bombardments.

edit: decided to add my tags because why not

#im stuck on the worldbuilding for this place  #I was curious about the Nova Empire in GotG too but we got a lot more screentime of them than we did of Hala so my brain is just going  #full speed ahead! on worldbuilding  #I’m disregarding the comics almost entirely here  #The Lower Hala concept art in the art book looks so cool!  #I imagine civilian fashions might be influenced by Starforce somewhat since they’re very public heroes-almost-celebrities#and while the Kree have been compared to the Roman Empire I can’t see togas being all that popular  #for a civilization that’s been at war and seems to value pragmatism#for like thousands of years

#im stuck on the worldbuilding for this place  #I was curious about the Nova Empire in GotG too but we got a lot more screentime of them than we did of Hala so my brain is just going  #full speed ahead! on worldbuilding  #I’m disregarding the comics almost entirely here  #The Lower Hala concept art in the art book looks so cool!  #I imagine civilian fashions might be influenced by Starforce somewhat since they’re very public heroes-almost-celebrities#and while the Kree have been compared to the Roman Empire I can’t see togas being all that popular  #for a civilization that’s been at war and seems to value pragmatism#for like thousands of years

i should be doing my assignments, but I took thirty minutes to make a rough painting of a Kree Civilian from lower Hala instead aslaksdjlakjsdka

It’s really rough because I was just trying to get an idea down. No short skirts or whatever here, since I figure Lower Hala is cooler than Upper Hala, what with them being largely shielded by Upper Hala from the sun and (presumably) bombardments.

edit: decided to add my tags because why not

#im stuck on the worldbuilding for this place  #I was curious about the Nova Empire in GotG too but we got a lot more screentime of them than we did of Hala so my brain is just going  #full speed ahead! on worldbuilding  #I’m disregarding the comics almost entirely here  #The Lower Hala concept art in the art book looks so cool!  #I imagine civilian fashions might be influenced by Starforce somewhat since they’re very public heroes-almost-celebrities#and while the Kree have been compared to the Roman Empire I can’t see togas being all that popular  #for a civilization that’s been at war and seems to value pragmatism#for like thousands of years

summary: what really annoys me about avengers endgame is that carol is wearing a tank top and a full face of makeup in the trailer, when...
body: what really annoys me about avengers endgame is that carol is wearing a tank top and a full face of makeup in the trailer, when she wears minimal/stage makeup in the captain marvel movie and we don’t see her shoulders once (except maybe as a child). stop sexualizing our tomboy superhero
